I give an entire seminar on the very topic. People who mocked Clinton for saying "depends on what the definition of the word is is" have not thought enough about the meaning of words.

If I use a half-note in place of the letter "p" or "d" in the logo of a musical group - is that a half-note or is it a letter? It depends on what the definition of "is" is!

Polymath - both "spinster" and "bachelor" originally denoted young people; the application over time was to people who continued to exist in the state of life of unmarried people past the expected age of marrying. They were the "never-got-around-to-its" of the world.

It was only a short hop and a skip to applying the names to those who were forbidden to properly marry until the recent [horrors!] activism on the part of the supremes - "confirmed bachelor" "maiden aunt" "lifelong companion" etc etc

Or, as the children in my choirs often put it, "But where is your wife? Why don't you have a wife?" The adults I work with are more reserved on the point...

You bring up a good point about the presence of video cameras at the 2 deaths. During that same time frame, since the death of Alton Sterling, 10 other people have died at the hands of police. But none of those were caught on film. They've received virtually no coverage by the national press.
(NY TIMES are you reading this?)
I would like to see police oversight elevated to the national level, with federal legislation mandating certain measures such as mandatory body cams on police officers, with the video obtained being the property of civilian review boards, i.e. police departments being unable to withhold its release.

Deputy Chief Aziz's statement, “We should be held accountable, and that is what we have a criminal justice system for,” is refreshing, but the problem is that the police are seldom held accountable when they clearly commit wrongful and even criminal acts.

Nothing happened to those responsible for Eric Garner's death and many others. Washington Post documented many such cases in their article, "Thousands Dead, Few Prosecuted." http://wapo.st/1OoBtwP

What's more, police officers, such as the ones involved in the killings in Louisiana and Minnesota, seem NOT to have gotten the message that it is NOT okay to shoot and kill people over minor infractions. Were it not for the videos of these shootings that clearly show the use of excessive and deadly force, the two cases would not have gotten any local attention, leave alone national attention.

The kind of indifference shown by rogue police officers to people's lives, especially those of blacks and other minorities, will lead people to take the law into their own hands, as happened in Dallas, however despicable that is. Hopefully there won't be any others. However, if the elected representatives and the police don't do anything--and soon--about the excessive and fatal use of force by police against people, they'd be inviting more tragedies such as the one in Dallas.
I don't think so, Martin. I just use he monument as a way of figuring how far to go. If I had known you'd stayed in Duck, I would have gone to Figure Eight Island.

Suspected of what?  Driving while black? A broken tail light? Daring to carry a gun while Black?  I only see reasons for walking through life not being murdered by someone whose salary is paid by taxes.

I speak as a retired officer with 25 years of experience.  The brutal murder of the officers is horrible and inexcusable.  The killing of the men in Minnesota and Louisiana still need to be investigated of course.  But its not hard by most standards to look at what we saw and make some conclusions. In the Minnesota case the officer overreacted, that's putting it mildly. He was also probably very afraid of approaching a "black man," at night.  This is guy that should probably never have been hired in the first place.  In the Louisiana case the two officers should have been able to subdue him without deadly force. You can see in the video the officer removing the gun from his pocket after he is shot. Those officers lacked the training and physical strength to do the job properly.  I doubt I'll be proved wrong.

Your initial reaction to the two cases in Minnesota and Louisiana is mine as well. I've seen officers -- men and women -- who are very short and slight as well as officers who are clearly overweight and out of shape. I wonder how much more likely they are to resort to a Taser or, God forbid, a gun when confronted with an unreasonable suspect they can't talk down. I suspect we have a lot of war veterans on small town police forces who may or may not have PTSD and may respond with too much force to a scuffle between two town drunks or a domestic. But some of the situations they walk into willingly are harrowing and I understand why they are afraid. I've seen officers testify in court and read their affidavits. I don't think the general public has any real idea of what a cop does or how quickly a routine stop can escalate into a life or death struggle out of the blue. Training should be looked at and hiring practices should be looked at, but we also need to respect police.

The Dallas police who were killed were innocent victims shot in the line of duty by a black man. Of that we know for sure. What is less certain is the innocence of the suspects who were shot in Minnesota and Louisiana. And we won't know for sure until the facts are in and the investigations are complete.

When increased dietary fiber is tested in experimental trials, it doesn't appear to do much of anything relative to the control group. I do think fiber is important, but it is likely a marker or indicator of a relatively unprocessed diet.

I look at this over the span of 60 years or more. Many of these interact, many take a long time to effect change. And too many medical researchers only want to use the latest toys which having nothing to do with what happened over time.

What I've witness in my adult life:

Causes outside of lifestyle: vaccines - removing the stresses of illnesses from diphtheria, measles, mumps, scarlet fever, influenza, etc. - add in fluoridation of water, removing lead from gasoline, diminishing acid rain, ending coal in home heating.

Causes within lifestyle: aerobic exercise - especially jogging and walking - fitness including lifetime sports [this more so outside the US excepting racquet sports], myriad of diets - even fad diets - all increase dietary fibre.

The sum of all this is a healthier lifestyle in the United States than any other on this scale. While other smaller countries often surpass the US model, medium and larger educated nations are fast accomplishing the same. And we affect each other.
To equate Hillary Clinton with Donald Trump, or any other Republican, is like comparing a horse to a snake.

If Steven Rattner believes the Republican Party seeks to promote fiscal responsibility he suffers from a ghastly illusion. The Republican Party exists to protect and promote the interests, including wealth and power, of an economic elite. It cuts funding from the IRS to reduce the possibility of awkward tax audits. TSA lines mean little to people who fly on private aircraft or spend their time in luxury lounges waiting to be ushered to first-class seating. Spending on collective goods and services, e.g. the EPA or urban water systems, benefits this elite far less than low taxes, privileges, and subsidies. And why on earth should it be concerned with timely responses to taxpayer communications with the I.R.S.?
The charade that Donald Trump, or for that matter Hillary Clinton, somehow represent threats to core Republican concerns is precisely that. To the extent Trump has revealed his thinking on tax policy it is consistent with the most extreme faction of the Republican Party. Trump's grand accomplishment is to construct an alliance between the true economic interests of the Republican Party and the that segment of the American electorate largely marginalized and displaced by the actions of that same elite. Clinton represents the corporate wing of the Democratic Party and is disposed to collaborate with Republicans, but Trump's triumph is to focus the ire of the dispossessed on the weak and marginalized in support of powerful predators heedless of America's future.

A local example of underfunding, in Florida, is the Herbert Hoover dike encircling Lake Okeechobee. It's in poor shape, and it's the responsibility of the US Army Corps of Engineers, an agency that's authorized to do a great many projects but funded to do few, often excruciatingly slowly. So the Corps has to stage big, abrupt releases of algae and nutrient-laden water from the lake, resulting in an ugly, smelly mess that's getting national attention.

The lake situation is further entangled in water pollution management in the Kissimmee River basin (from Lake Okeechobee north to Orlando) and in the Everglades.

Politically, the Florida state government is trying to cut taxes, cut state agencies (including the once-busy Water Management Districts), and keep the EPA from meddling in Florida issues.

I am willing to guess that the Okeechobee dike will be rebuilt after a Katrina-type event, likely as not with a lot of drowned people. Likewise with any number of other government responsibilities.

I have seen the taxes on my earnings and on my property go to support schools they've for the most part rejected. I saw additional subsidies go into their districts on a per pupil basis and still there is rejection.
I have watched the bleeding hearts destroy what civilized culture they did have be destroyed with food stamps, rent subsidies that relieved them of the responsibilities of life. Most of them didn't have Grandparents that lived as they do today. I saw them as they rode the buses and subways to crummy jobs. I saw them married to the same spouse all their lives and going to church on Wednesday nights and most of Sunday. They rejected that culture.
I grew up in a ghetto. Almost all of who had family that was first or second generation did. But we worked to get out of those ghettos. We had large families and our Fathers lived in the home and we didn't have half siblings down the street.
It's a lot harder for them today because fewer people care what they do any more or where they'll end up. The immigrants don't for sure. The Left is out of ideas. Throwing money at them didn't work and it wasn't enough anyway. When they stopped caring about themselves what were we to do? Disproportionate arrests? How about disproportionate criminal behavior? The murders and killers of the day all have Black faces. "One death is a tragedy. A million a statistic." That's what they've become. Statistics.
Thank you, Charles.

Look at the pain in Governor Dayton's face when he
first responded to the shooting in Minnesota.
He was anguished. It was genuine. President Obama was equally distraught.

There are a sea of us out there who sickened by over-reactive police responses that result in the deaths of black men.

Are there bad guys who understand nothing unless a gun is pointed at them?---oh yes. The tragedy in racism is that it precludes us from identifying those
who are pro social and have deep regard for life.

I have spent 33 of my 67 years in law enforcement.
I do not want to offend anyone but looking back at all of that time my African-American friends/colleagues were my best teachers because,
in a patient way, they imbewed in me the importance of patience with those who were angry and magnanimity with those who had had little luck in life.

So---thank you Governor Dayton and President Obama for your willingness to show us your troubled hearts in a troubled time. More personally, I have tried to hold the importance of patience in my heart because the alternative, mean spirited threats and violence are simply unacceptable. The President is right, we can do better---we have to.

Politicians across America are corrupt, and immensely moreso among Republicans.  The NRA, one of the most evil lobbying bodies ever to disgrace our great and good democracy, holds Republicans by the neck with one hand, and disburses millions of dollars in bribes with the other.  If the NRA is a criminal organization, then so too are those politicians who do its bidding.  If not legally criminal, then surely morally criminal.  America needs to enforce the intent of the Second Amendment--"a well-regulated militia"--and by doing so, honor the wisdom of our founding fathers in their considered choice of words, and the intent of those words.  What is the alternative?  We are seeing the alternative--slaughters of children, of persons enjoying a night off, children accidentally killing a parent or sibling, the use of guns for racial hatred, church-goers murdered alongside their pulpit.  The American Federal government can stop this but Republicans prevent it.  So Republicans are complicit, and the deaths of innocent human beings darken their inhuman little hearts.

I agree with all you wrote. I would add that civilian review boards need to be created OUTSIDE of the police departments, with enough power to have a real influence over police decision making. This can only occur we have national legislation mandating this of all jurisdictions.
The people sitting on these boards should not be allowed to have any former relationships with police forces, such as marital, contractual or employment relationships.
They would ideally include people of all ethnic backgrounds because people of ALL backgrounds are the victims of police misconduct.

The fact of the matter is that young black men commit a disproportionate number of violent crimes in the US...look at the murder rate in Chicago now.  Police officers internalize this reality and react with fear when confronting young black male criminal suspects.  I think if young black males were not so disproportionately part of the criminal class police fears would moderate and the episodes of police over reaction would start to recede.  Young black males can contribute to this effort by not participating in the drug trade, not indulging in scary-looking gang type tattoos and no longer looking and acting like the thug-types that cops fear. On the other hand, police abuse of power in several well publicized incidents (the one in SC comes to mind), where broken tail lights are an excuse to stop and murder the black male drivers, has got to stop.  How about videotaping EVERY traffic stop as a standard police procedure, creating committees to review the tapes and including community members of color to review the recordings.  The power to pass on the criminality of police conduct against blacks must not rest exclusively in the hands of majority white reviewing bodies.  Whites have so badly abused their power in these situations that they have forfeited their right to pass on the review of white police officer misconduct by themselves (and I'm white myself).  We have to go out of our way to treat blacks fairly in order for them to be brought back into the political mainstream.

Not only that, but the gun legally carried by the young African-American man in Minnesota was what prompted the officer to shoot him. Perhaps that was also the case in Baton Rouge. However, one doubts the police would have reacted in the same way if the victims had been white.
Exactly.  That's why the NRA has been silent.

More and more guns will only increase the likelihood of more tragic gun deaths...

It was a military grade bomb with C-4 that killed the suspect. Not a gun.
I hope this does not become an "arm" protected by the 2nd amendment.

Those who would see some justification in these mass murders need to understand that every terrorist has grievances, and some of those are compelling.  But in every case, the killing of innocent human beings is still murder.  And it is still just as wrong-- it's the way that wars begin that kill myriads of innocents, with the murderers all feeling righteous as they kill.  It has to be refused, and without tolerance whatsoever.  Justice demands it on every hand.  Do the parents of those killed want more innocent people killed as retaliation?  No.  They want the guilty punished.  That is justice.  This act in Dallas?  Terrorism, and entirely that.

In this context, the vast majority of killings with firearms are by police. But, if your proposing that most police really don't need to carry guns, then I am in complete agreement.

The average police officer has no need to carry and gun. They can learn to retreat, wait for back up, and use de-escalation tactics to resolve the situation peacefully.

We should expect this kind of thing in a democracy. It's the risk we take. It's a fad, a stage, a thing people do for a while when they view making generalizations about groups, like cops, or Blacks, or Jews or white people, as some profound and intellectually honest form thinking. Labels are always wrong, unless you're a can of Campbell's soup, perhaps.

In democracy, here comes everybody. It's the rule of the mob that's in style and reason is too laborious. It cuts into TV, or social media time, or delays the instant gratification one gets with a gun or a box of supersize fries and soda.

Nobody want's to be tyrannized by what is reasonable. Reason isn't sexy. Balance isn't sexy. The murdered can't forgive because they're not here anymore to do that. Anybody who has learned that they are a member group of people whose ancestors were mistreated, raise your hands. That's not at issue. The question is can the cycle be broken and if so, how.
